conclusion: The triangle is equilateral with a side length of a and moves uniformly to the right at speed v.
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the plane of the loop.
Induced emf is given by Faraday's Law: \( \mathcal{E} = -\frac{d\Phi_B}{dt} \).
Area A is determined by how much of the triangle is in the field.
Initially, only part of the triangle's base is in the magnetic field.
As the loop moves, the area in the magnetic field increases linearly with time.
Maximum emf occurs when the rate of change of flux is maximized.
For a triangular loop moving into the magnetic field: \( \mathcal{E} = B \cdot v \cdot L \).
When the loop starts entering the field, the side length L in the field is the same as side length a.
Maximum emf is \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = B \cdot v \cdot a \).
